On [[24 November]] [[1966]], [[J.R.R. Tolkien]] wrote '''[[Letters not published in The Letters of J.R.R. Tolkien|a letter]] to Professor Harry C. Bauer'''.<ref group=note>Harry Charles Bauer (1902-1978), born in St. Louis, Missouri, was a graduate of  the St. Louis Library School. Bauer served as a professor of library science at the University of Washington. (Source: [http://content.lib.washington.edu/cdm4/item_viewer.php?CISOROOT=/portraits&CISOPTR=231 Digital Collections: Harry C. Bauer and Lulu Fairbanks examining the Eric A. Hegg photograph albums, n.d.], at [http://www.lib.washington.edu/ University Libraries, University of Washington] (accessed 17 August 2013).)</ref><ref name=Sac>{{webcite|author=[[John D. Rateliff]]|articleurl=http://sacnoths.blogspot.com/2013/08/tolkien-and-sinclair-lewis.html|articlename=Tolkien and Sinclair Lewis|dated=15 August 2013|website=Sac|accessed=17 August 2013}}</ref>

*'''Subject:''' Tolkien thanks Bauer for an article or reprint Bauer had sent him. While the text Bauer sent is unknown, [[John D. Rateliff]] has noted that "it must have had something to do with the work of [[Wikipedia:Sinclair Lewis|Sinclair Lewis]], since Tolkien immediately segues into saying that he is now inclined to think that the word ''[[Hobbits|hobbit]]'' owes something to Lewis's [[Wikipedia:Babbitt (novel)|''Babbitt'']]". Tolkien also states in the letter that "he read all of Sinclair Lewis" (apparently referring to Lewis's famous books).<ref name=Sac/>
*'''Description:''' Typed letter.<ref name=Sac/>
